title: Christine Lampard says feels safe stalker free mum uses app tracker
story:
Christof King (left) has admitted stalking Christine Lampard (right with her husband Frank at the Pride of Britain awards) and was also found to have sent menacing tweets to her 'My mum has Find My Friends on my iPhone so she can keep track of everything I'm doing,' she told the Mirror.'I'm 39… if I stay out late she knows about it and where I've been. She's always asking why I stayed out so late.'But I've come out the other end. It wasn't ideal. I feel safer now.'King, who wanted career advice from Lampard, sent tweets and letters and turned up at her house on more than one occasion, causing her to hide in a bedroom with the housekeeper.At a court hearings last month, Lampard said the man who 'made her life a misery' during a three-year stalking campaign started by sending her 'dark, sinister and incoherent tweets'.  Mrs Lampard, said her mother Mina who she is pictured with on a shopping trip in Chelsea, London, uses the find my iPhone app to track her    King, who wanted career advice from Lampard, sent tweets and letters and turned up at her house on more than one occasion          When King turned up at her house, Lampard said she immediately recognised him from the tweets he sent The wife of England and Chelsea footballer Frank Lampard said King would hang around outside the couple's home and sent her bizarre letters.He sent threatening tweets including one saying he was 'sharpening nails for her crucifixion'.Speaking from behind a red curtain, Mrs Lampard, 39, who is pregnant, told the court she first started noticing Tweets from King in late 2015.She later told the court King later turned up at her home and she immediately recognised him as 'the man from Twitter', with her husband speaking to him while she hid in a bedroom. The court heard King conducted a campaign of harassment between January 2015 and last September.Mrs Lampard said that at first the Twitter posts were 'incoherent waffle' but they soon became 'sinister' which made her 'sit up and pay attention'.  Christine Lampard and her husband Frank attending court. King is due back for sentencing on July 27In statement to the court Mr Lampard told how King turned up at their mansion on October 13 and his wife saw him loitering at their front gate.He said his wife and the housekeeper, Chona Angel, 'hid in the bedroom' because they were so frightened.Mr Lampard added: 'It has both made us feel very vulnerable, she became flustered and very nervous and concerned for her safety.'I could see that Christine was very anxious and shaken more than I have ever seen.'Prosecutor Alistair Smith told Isleworth Crown Court last week that King believed it was his destiny to be with the presenter. V PRESENTER AND FIANCEE TO FOOTBALLER FRANK LAMPARD, CHRISTINE BLEAKLEY IS SEEN SHOPPING WITH HER LOOKALIKE MUM MINA BLEAKLEY IN CHELSEA, LONDON.

title: Queen refusing knee surgery does not miss royal engagements
story: The Queen, pictured here on the final day of the Royal Ascot, is reportedly refusing to have surgery on her knees because she does not want to miss any engagements          A source said: 'People from her and Philip's generation battle through problems and carry on. And Her Majesty doesn't like to cause any fuss' (pictured: the Queen with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex last week)'People from her and Philip's generation battle through problems and carry on. And Her Majesty doesn't like to cause any fuss.'Last month it was revealed that Her Majesty had successful surgery to remove a cataract in May.She had been seen wearing sunglasses at many events  including watching the Epsom Derby and a number of Buckingham Palace garden parties.Now it's Air Miles Sophie! Countess of Wessex saddles the...Meghan and Serena Williams join the polo set: The Duchess of...Share this articleThe eye operation, believed to be on or around May 4, is the most common procedure on the NHS.Although the Queen did not wear sunglasses at the royal wedding, she was seen wearing dark tinted shades the next morning as she left Windsor.The Queen is known for her robust health. Her husband Prince Philip, 96, is the same, but he has recently retired from public duties.          The Queen is known for her robust health. Last month it was revealed that Her Majesty had successful surgery to remove a cataract in May, but wore sunglasses to engagements instead of cancelling themTheir son the Duke of York once described his mother as being incredibly fit for her age, and she still rides her Fell ponies at Windsor, and drives, mainly around her private estates.Although she called time on her overseas travels, leaving long-haul destinations to the younger members of her family, she still has a busy diary of events - carrying out 296 engagements in 2017. The year before she used the lift rather than stairs to enter Parliament for the State Opening, avoiding the 26 steps of the royal staircase at the Sovereign's Entrance. The decision was attributed to the Queen suffering from knee pain.Her first hospital stay in 10 years came in 2013 when she was 86 after she suffered symptoms of gastroenteritis and missed an engagement in Swansea when she was due to present St David's Day leeks to the 3rd Battalion The Royal Welsh. The Queen is refusing to get knee surgery so she does not miss any engagements

title: Who Andr s Manuel L pez Obrador AMLO revealed Mexico election win
story: Andrés Manuel López Obrador waves after voting as part of the Mexico presidential electionAndrés Manuel López ObradorAndrés Manuel López Obrador has become the new President of Mexico after winning his third attempt at the presidency and 13 years of pursuing the highest office.Known as AMLO, he has forged through two presidential defeats, two gubernatorial losses and a heart attack in 2013, according to Al Jazeera.Born on November 13, 1953, in the southeastern state of Tabasco, he started his political career in the indigenous affairs bureau for the area in the 1970s. AMLO was then a member of the PRI party, led by President Enrique Pena Nieto, but quit in the late 1980s.After losing the Tabasco governor’s race twice, he staged protests in an attempt to raise his profile during a time in which there was increasing resistance towards the leading party. However, in 2000, AMLO was elected as the mayor of Mexico City as part of the PRD.With his first bid at the presidency in 2006, he promised to ‘put the poor first’, but his critics branded him ‘a danger for Mexico’, likening him to Venezuela’s President Hugo Chavez. The election was decided by a thin margin and López Obrador claimed it had been rigged.          Mexico City's main square, the Zocalo, as Andrés Manuel López Obrador delivers his speechAMLO led protests yet again and declared that he was the legitimate president of Mexico. This led to the former Mayor speaking in villages that had not been visited by political leaders for years.One of his aides, Polimnia Romana Sierra said: ‘He spoke with the same energy under a tree in front of 10 people as he did in the full Zocalo. Nobody works the microphone like him.’He formed a new party, the National Regeneration Movement (MORENA) and by 2015, he was regarded as the next election winner. In addition to this, as the PRI became increasingly involved in corruption scandals, López Obrador also grew in popularity.His wife and fervent feminist, Beatriz Gutierrez, also helped to extend his appeal to female voters in Mexico.          AMLO, accompanied by wife Beatriz Gutierrez Muller, delivers his victory speech in MexicoAndrés Manuel López Obrador's policiesAfter winning the Mexican election, Andrés Manuel López Obrador must now ensure that his promises are fulfilled. Despite critics comparing AMLO to Hugo Chavez and his leftist sympathies could turn Mexico into Venezuela, he took home a landslide victory.According to the BBC, many believe that he shares an authoritarian approach and will ruin the economy, but AMLO has rejected these claims and has said that he will not carry out expropriations and will not seek re-election.However, he has promised to renew contracts awarded by the state oil company Pemex to private companies during the administration of President Enrique Pena Nieto and will check they are not corrupt. He has also vowed to bring economic growth, jobs and social development programmes.‘We will carry out a peaceful transformation, ordered, but profound and even radical, because the word radical comes from root, and what we will do... is, in essence, to root out the corrupt regime,’ he said at one campaign rally.Against what he describes as the ‘power mafia’ of Mexico, he plans to increase scholarships for the young and expand welfare for the elderly, offering ‘good relations’ with the private sector and accusing business leaders of acting ‘like they owned Mexico’.AMLO has also promised to bring peace to the war on drugs, but will not continue the military-led strategy. Notably, he has also said that he would not let Mexico bow down to Trump and asked for ‘friendship’ and ‘mutual respect’ to avoid any trade war.'Soon, very soon, after the victory of our movement, we will defend migrants all over the American continent and the migrants of the world who, by necessity, must abandon their towns to find life in the United States it's a human right we will defend,' Lopez Obrador said in a June speech reported by El Universal.US President Donald Trump congratulated Lopez Obrador in a tweet saying: 'Congratulations to Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador on becoming the next President of Mexico. I look very much forward to working with him. There is much to be done that will benefit both the United States and Mexico!'Who is Morgan Evans? title: US hints FRANCE closest military ally
story: Theresa May told MPs today (pictured) that Britain had the largest defence budget in Europe and the second largest among Nato members           Donald Trump (pictured at the White House with First Lady Melania yesterday) is expected to heap pressure on NATO members to spend more at what could be a bad-tempered summit next week          In a letter to his British counterpart, Defence Secretary Jim Mattis (pictured) suggested the UK might not continue to be a 'global actor' unless funding was increased           Just six NATO countries meet the 2 per cent of GDP target for spending on their military forcesDonald Trump is expected to heap pressure on NATO members to spend more at what could be a bad-tempered summit next week.  In the missive, seen by The Sun, General Mattis told Mr Williamson that Washington is 'concerned' the UK's forces and diplomatic influence are 'at risk of erosion'.He said he wanted Britain to remain America's 'partner of choice' - but added that the French were committed to being 'global actors' alongside the US. Mr Trump will travel to Europe next week for a potentially stormy NATO gathering on July 11-12, before heading to the UK.In the two-page letter, Gen Mattis said 'the credibility of the UK's armed forces' had been crucial in securing its place on the world stage.David Cameron DID ask Barack Obama to warn that Brexit would...Tory Brexit war catches fire as minister demands 'insolent'...Share this articleBut he added: 'I am concerned that your ability to continue to provide this critical military foundation for diplomatic success is at risk of erosion, while together we face a world awash with change.'The UK is committed to meeting the Nato target of spending 2 per cent of GDP on defence, but the US hinted that it wants Mrs May to commit more money.Gen Mattis said: 'A global nation like the UK, with interests and commitments around the world, will require a level of defence spending beyond what we would expect from allies with only regional interests.'Absent a vibrant military arm, world peace and stability would be at further risk.'Highlighting Mr Macron's recent pledge to pump an extra £260billion into defence by 2025, Gen Mattis said: 'As global actors, France and the US have concluded that now is the time to significantly increase our investment in defence.'Other allies are following suit.'          The letter has been leaked as Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson (pictured left with Mrs May and her husband Philip at an Armed Forces Day event over the weekend) lobbies hard for his budget to be expanded    Mr Trump and French president Emmanuel Macron (pictured together at the White House in April) have struck up a close rapportHe stressed that it was 'in the best interest of both our nations for the UK to remain the US partner of choice' but 'in that spirit, the UK will need to invest and maintain robust military capability'.In a reference to the Whitehall rows over funding, Gen Mattis added: 'It is not for me to tell you how to prioritise your domestic spending priorities, but I hope the UK will soon be able to share with us a clear, and fully funded, forward defence blueprint that will allow me to plan our own future engagement with you from a position of strength and confidence.'Downing Street tried to play down the row, insisting Britain has the 'biggest defence budget in Europe and the second biggest in Nato'.‘I would point to the Nato Secretary General following his meeting with the PM where he said he appreciates Britain’s commitment and leadership in the Alliance,' the PM's spokesman said.‘The UK is above the 2 per cent contribution and we have said we will continue to meet that target.‘We, the US and France are close allies and partners willing to take action together in defence of our values.’However, the spokesman refused to state that the UK would continue to have the largest defence budget in Europe.   The week after receiving the letter, Mr Williamson told MPs that US patience over European defence spending was wearing thin.'We can't continue to expect US taxpayers to keep picking up the tab for European defence indefinitely, nor can we expect US patience to last forever,' he said on June 20.The Commons Defence Committee has also called for a significant funding boost, moving the level of defence spending up from 2 per cent to 3 per cent of total GDP.A cash injection on this scale would equate to additional funding of around £20billion a year and bring investment in defence to levels similar to those seen between the end of the Cold War and the mid-1990s.

title: Pictured Commoner shipping worker 32 marry Japanese princess
story: Japan's Princess Ayako (right) has unveiled her 'commoner' fiance Kei Moriya (left) to the world ahead of a marriage which will mean the end of her royal status          The 27-year-old princess, a relative of Emperor Akihito, will marry 32-year-old Kei Moriya (left)          The princess unveiled her fiance, who works for a shipping company, to the world today           Princess Ayako, who will give up her Japanese royal status, speaks at today's press conference          The princess said she had met Moriya in December last year and fallen in love with his 'kind, smart and decisive' personality          Journalists watch on as Princess Ayako and her fiance Kei Moriya speak to the press today The princess said: 'I don't know what my mother's intentions were in introducing him to me, but as the two of us went to various places together and shared our time and memories, we became naturally drawn to each other. 'I think we were able to come this far thanks to the wonderful ties started by our mothers.' Her fiance, who proposed to her at a restaurant, said he had fallen in love with the 'bright and positive' princess.  Female members of the Imperial family have no claim to the Chrysanthemum Throne.William tells Israel 'hope and reconciliation is needed' as...Brexit comes a step closer as Speaker John Bercow announces...Unseen images of The Beatles filming a promo for Penny Lane...Share this articleAs with all women in her family, the princesses will lose their royal status upon marriage to commoners  - a law that does not apply to male members of the family.In September last year, Princess Mako, Emperor Akihito's oldest grandchild, and her college classmate Kei Komuro announced their engagement.   Unlike her cousin Mako, Ayako is not a direct descendent of Emperor Akihito, who is planning to abdicate next year.Mako announced plans to engage one for the Imperial Household Agency to reveal in February that the wedding, originally set for November, would be delayed until 2020, citing lack of time for preparations           Princess Mako (right) is engaged to Kei Komuro (left). But in Japan women are not allowed to succeed the throne, meaning that when the pair, both 25, tie the knot, she will lose her status          Emperor Akihito (left, with Empress Michiko at the centenary reception of the foundation of the America-Japan Society in Tokyo in April this year) has won plaudits for seizing upon the constitutionally-prescribed role of national symbolAkihito's three other grandchildren are all women so after Hisahito, the only person left in the line of succession is Princess Mako's younger brother. After that there are no more eligible males, meaning the centuries-old succession would be broken if the young heirs do not have any sons of their own.So far the monarchy has an unbroken 2,600-year-long line of male succession. Those who are concerned about the future of the royal family want to allow women to succeed the throne and others to keep their royal status so they can keep performing public duties - but a government panel on the emperor's abdication avoided the isive issue. Traditionalists, including Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, strenuously oppose such changes, even though Japan has occasionally been ruled by female sovereigns in past centuries.                            In September last year, Princess Mako (left), Emperor Akihito's oldest grandchild, and her college classmate Kei Komuro (right) announced their engagement When Naruhito, who has a daughter but no sons, ascends the throne, his younger brother Akishino will be next in line, followed by Hisahito, Akishino's 10-year-old son. But if Hisahito doesn't have a son there will be a succession crisis. Pictured: Emperor Akihito's family tree       Japanese Princess Ayako to marry shipping employee, leave royal family - CNNJapan's Princess Ayako says she and fiance Kei Moriya hit it off from the start | The Japan Times

title: Pope Francis makes touching friendship Pope Benedict appointment 14 new cardinals
story: Pope Francis embracing his predecessor at a ceremony to appoint 14 new cardinals in the Vatican          The two men shared a few intimate words before the ceremony. Benedict lives in near isolation in the Vatican Earlier this year it emerged he is battling a disease of his nervous system which means he often needs to use a wheelchair.Benedict said he is in the last phase of life and on a 'pilgrimage towards home' in a letter published in an Italian newspaper.The 81-year-old Pope Francis appointed 14 new from countries Iraq, Pakistan, Madagascar and Japan whom he warned to avoid the kind of 'palace intrigues' which have plagued the Vatican over the years.Each new appointee knelt in front of Pope Francis who placed the cardinal's hat on their heads during the ceremony at St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican.The appointments come as the Argentine pontiff gradually shapes a less European college of cardinals.Before the ceremony marking their appointment, Francis warned the new batch of cardinals that they must not get involved in 'palace intrigues' within the Vatican but focus on 'those who are hungry, the forgotten, the prisoner, the sick, the addict, the abandoned person'.          It recently emerged Benedict was suffering from a disease of the central nervous system Among the most prominent is Iraq's Louis Raphael Sako who has often met Pope Francis to discuss the situation in the war-torn country and the plight of the dwindling Christian community.One third of the Christian families in the north of the country were able to return to their land after the collapse of the Islamic State group, often with funds raised by the church.Sako believes 400,000-500,000 Christians now living in Iraq, compared to 1.5 million before the fall of Saddam Hussein's regime in 2003.Speaking at the beginning of the ceremony, Sako hailed 'the special attention from the Pope... for the small flock of Christians in the Middle East, in Pakistan and other countries that are going through a difficult period because of wars and sectarianism and where there are still martyrs.'  Francis and Benedict with the news cardinals, who come from a total of 14 countries Speaking about his homeland, he said:'It's is our land, we were here before the arrival of Muslims', Sako told journalists on Wednesday.He advocates 'dialogue' and challenges 'a vision of a uniquely Islamic nation'.Also appointed was Pakistani bishop Joseph Coutts of Karachi who promotes dialogue between Christians and Muslims.Coutts fights the abusive use of the crime of blasphemy in a country where churches are under police protection due to threats from extremist Muslim groups.Pope Francis Ireland visit: All you need to know about the...Share this articleThe Pope also appointed Thomas Aquinas Manyo from Osaka in Japan and aong the three Latin American prelates is Archbishop Pedro Barreto of Huancayo, Peru.Barreto fights for the rights of the communities living in the Amazon forest and has received death threats for denouncing working conditions in illegal mines.Seven European cardinals were also appointed, including Italy's Giuseppe Petrocchi, archbishop of L'Aquila, a city destroyed nine years ago by a violent earthquake.Benedict resigned following a turbulent papacy that included the so-call 'Vatileaks' case, in which his butler leaked some of his personal letters and other documents that alleged corruption and a power struggle in the Vatican.

title: Adorable moment chimpanzee reunited foster parents
story: Limbani was seen drinking through a straw when he hears someone call his name from behind (left) and sees it is his foster parent Jorge (right)The chimp makes sure that his arms are wrapped tightly around the man's neck and his legs around his waist during the loving embrace.Limbani is then quickly distracted after seeing Jorge's wife, Tania, walk into the room. He lets out another excited sound before reaching out to her and giving her a cuddle.The heart-warming footage was posted on Instagram by the Zoological Wildlife Foundation in Miami, who say the couple helped provide the animal with 'around the clock care for the first few months of his life'.Limbani is now staying at the zoo, but regularly sees the couple who raised him when they visit. And even though there can be months between visits, the foundation said the Limbani's reaction is 'always the same' when he is reunited with them.Limbani was rejected after he was born with pneumonia and rejected by his mother.  Limbani could not hide his excitement as he gives Jorge a hug (left). Limbani hit headlines in January when a video of him with a Mastiff dog, named Bruno cuddling went viral.Another video on the Zoo's website shows 'bundle of love' Limbani playing with a golden Tabby tiger cub.

title: Footage shows undertaking Mercedes driver swerving traffic
story: Peter Goodfellow, 36, was jailed for 11 months after the horrifying crash which sent the Mini spinning across three lanes          Video shows Goodfellow undertaking other vehicles as he whizzes down the motorway at dangerous speed.          These dramatic dash-cam images show the moment a speed maniac weaves in and out of motorway traffic at upwards of 100mph, before colliding into a mini at top speedHe was also found to have two bald tyres on his white Mercedes C250 vehicle at the time of the incident on July 19 last year.The smash happened on the M4 carriageway westbound, at the Leigh Delamere services near Chippenham.Goodfellow, of Swindon, Wiltshire, was sentenced at Swindon Crown Court last Friday to 11 months behind bars.Terrifying moment a baby in a buggy rolls off the pavement...Dramatic moment driver, 57, attempts to flee traffic stop...Share this articleHe was also disqualified from driving for 29 months, after which time he will need to retake his driving test. He must pay a victim surcharge of £140.The female driver of the Mini suffered minor injuries.PC Will Ayres, of Wiltshire Police Roads Policing Unit, said: 'Dash cam footage was invaluable in securing this conviction against Goodfellow.          The car hits the mini at top speed and sends it spinning across three lanes of traffic          eter Goodfellow, aged 36 years, was arrested after police arrived at the scene and requested dash-cam footage from nearby cars whose drivers had seen the incident'He is a dangerous driver who had no regard for other road users. This was a busy time of day on a busy stretch of the M4.'Goodfellow put other road users lives at risk, not just by driving at excess speed, but also undertaking vehicles which led to a collision and left an innocent driver with injuries.'Thankfully, these injuries were minor although the incident has no doubt really affected her.'Looking at the dash cam footage provided by a witness, it is so lucky that nobody was more seriously injured.'           The dangerous white Mercedes pictured moments before the incident          The driver of the white Mercedes C250 was also found to have to bald tyres on his car, meaning the grip on the wheels had been excessively worn down, making an accident much more likely

title: Callous dog owners dump three five week old lurcher puppies driveway
story: The two surviving puppies went to RSPCA Leybourne Animal Centre where they were treated  Three starving lurcher cross puppies left too weak to stand were 'thrown away like rubbish' in a plastic box. One was put down but two brothers Bauer (pictured) and Boeser were taken in by the RSPCA          Sadly over the weekend over the weekend Boeser's condition went down hill and he died          But Bauer is doing really well though and is continuing to go from strength-to-strength But over the weekend Boeser's condition went down hill and he too did not survive.Now the animal charity is trying to trace the callous people who dumped the pups and left them to fend for themselves on June 21.A spokesman said: 'These poor pups had simply been abandoned, thrown away like rubbish and left to be someone else's problem.'It never ceases to amaze me how people can so cruelly cast animals aside like worthless objects.'These pups are only around five-weeks-old and certainly shouldn't be away from their mother so they'd never be able to survive for long on their own.'One of the dogs was rushed to the vets unable to stand and was unfortunately put to sleep on veterinary advice.The two surviving puppies went to RSPCA Leybourne Animal Centre where staff member Samantha Rogers has become their surrogate mum and is now fostering the pair.The lurcher cross pups - two boys called Bauer and Boeser - were given round-the-clock care at their new home in Rochester.Samantha said: 'The first few days were really rough as they were so weak but, with regular meals and lots of TLC they are slowly improving and getting stronger.'They're becoming more active every day and really enjoy chasing after and climbing all over their foster sister, my Staffie, Hera.'Sadly, Boeser's condition started to deteriorate rapidly over the weekend and despite her best efforts, he died.She said: 'Unfortunately we lost little Boeser. He went downhill really quickly and when they are so young it's difficult to help them.'His brother, Bauer, is doing really well though and continues to go from strength-to-strength.'Injured kangaroo shot with an arrow while carrying a joey in...Tormented bear is rescued after being tied to a pole and...Father shook his six-month-old baby boy to death causing...Share this article    Now the RSPCA is trying to trace the callous people who dumped the pups on the drivewayThe pup will stay with Samantha until he's healthy enough and old enough to start looking for a new home.The charity revealed that they deal with 149,000 complaints of cruelty and neglect every year and last year secured 1,492 convictions by private prosecution to protect animals against those who break the laws.

title: Animal outcasts sanctuary Britains wonderfully eccentric farm
story: No room in the barn for this nativity star: For the first few months of his life, Dougal was bottle-fed by members of the public at a farm park in their nativity scene. When he outgrew that and was being sent for slaughter, Manor Farm stepped in. ‘He’s a rascal,’ says Di. ‘Having been given lots of attention, he feels it’s his right to demand fuss from visitors, who are taken by surprise when he head-butts the back of their knees!’          Bullied pig called Simon: Partially-sighted and with deformed front legs, Simon was so terribly bullied by the bigger pigs he shared a sty with at another rescue centre that they asked Manor Farm to take him. ‘He was grossly overweight which didn’t help with his movement problems — if he was a human it’s like he’s walking on his wrists,’ says Di. ‘He’s now lost weight and is enjoying life with his friend Brooke. She chivvies him around all day and I give him strawberries and melon which he loves.’          Jack the VERY stroppy Donkey: Jack was the first non-hen to be taken in by Manor Farm rescue sanctuary after it came into being about seven years ago. ‘We bought the land for it with some money left to me by my Uncle Jack,’ says Di, ‘so when a donkey sanctuary asked me to look after a donkey called Jack it seemed meant to be. The only thing is — he’s nothing like my Uncle Jack who was very gentle whereas donkey Jack is quite stroppy!’Less than a decade ago, Di and Alan were both running businesses from their Nottinghamshire village home.Now they’re also running an animal sanctuary that currently cares for more than 100 farmyard creatures. And not just any creatures. They take in the ones no one else wanted, rejected because they were disabled, had health problems, special needs or simply grew too old.Or, in the case of the many rescued from petting zoos, simply because they grew up. ‘People imagine these animals are living a lovely life in the petting zoo until they die naturally,’ says Di, ‘but that’s not so in the majority of cases.Adorable moment Limbani the chimpanzee shrieks with joy and...Fury at female Kentucky hunter who posted sickening photos...Share this article‘Lambs can be bred out of season to be Christmas attractions to be bottle-fed by visitors but once they’ve grown out of the cute stage, they go into the food chain.’What’s more, they often come to her emaciated, neglected and infested with parasites. Then the battle is on to save their lives. That battle costs Manor Farm Charitable Trust up to £100,000 a year — around a fifth of which are vets’ bills.‘Our vets are constantly challenged by the ageing of our animals,’ Di admits.No wonder — it’s rare farmyard creatures live more than a year or two before going to be slaughtered.          Blind Stevie's a littler wonder: When blind Stevie the Mallard duck came to Manor Farm, they knew he needed a friend to guide him round. ‘I chose a girl called Wanda,’ says Di, ‘because female ducks are louder than the boys and I believed he needed someone noisy to follow around.’ Stevie was found with big scabs over his eyes. ‘We didn’t know at first if he’d been attacked, if they were infected or even if he had eyes. He did — but he was blind.’ Now Wanda’s his guide duck.          Toothless OAP fed on a banana: Life’s left Dolly so scared of human strangers that when summer comes Di can’t call in a shearer —instead she has to do it herself with nail scissors. Dolly, a breeding nanny at a farm park, came to Manor Farm in 2012 when they started neglecting her because she’d become barren. ‘She barely had the strength to hold her head up,’ says Di. ‘But she had an indomitable spirit we could all do with.’ Dolly, who has no teeth, was fattened up with mashed banana and is now in the equivalent of her 90s.          Stumble, duck who live up to his name: Stumble may only have one leg but he’s still the scourge of the female ducks he shares his enclosure with. ‘He’s perfected the ability to jump on to a mate,’ says Di. ‘They all run but they can’t hide from him. Stumble’s leg had to be amputated after getting caught in fishing wire. He’s had a difficult summer because he’s moulted and lost his tail feather and wing tips — which help keep him stable. So he keeps falling over.’ And falling in love.          Goat that costs £3,000 to perk up: Of all the Manor Farm animals, Jo cost the most. So thin when Di rescued him from a petting zoo that he couldn’t hold his neck up, she nursed him back to health in her kitchen. ‘He came up to me as if to say “help me,” ’ she says. Jo was covered in lice and had digestive problems. ‘We nearly lost him several times — he was always the one needing the vet at midnight,’ says Di. But she doesn’t begrudge a penny of the £3,000 he cost. ‘He’s the sweetest creature,’ she says.But it’s not just the vets who have been learning. Di has too. ‘In 2010 I treated myself to four hens as a reward for completing an MA in creative writing and I found it was a slippery slope ,’ she says.A year later, a relative died, leaving her money to buy the six-acre field behind the house. Slowly the brood grew and the dozen or so enclosures now house 64 hens, 27 goats, two donkeys, one pony, two pigs and 30 sheep.Di now employs a full-time member of staff and three part-timers. Every day begins at 6am when she gets the feed ready. It ends at 10.30pm — earlier in winter — when she puts the animals to bed. She also finds time to run her publishing business (and Alan his marketing consultancy firm) which help bankroll Manor Farm.          Ewe with a stiff neck: Born with a twisted neck, Hilda was too deformed to breed and too skinny to slaughter so Di took the tiny ewe in. 'We were told she'd never take to humans,' she eat out of a trough because she'd never seen them before. But within a month she was letting us touch her and gradually she got a lust for life. Now she loves to be cuddled and her tail wags madly like a big dog          A goat the size of a pony: Ronnie, the Anglo Nubian goat, is the size of a Shetland pony. ‘They’re a large breed but he’s a particular giant,’ says Di, ‘and that’s how he ended up here — his elderly owner couldn’t cope with the size of him and was going to have him shot.’ So she did a 135-mile round trip to save him. ‘I knew he was big but even so it was a bit of a shock when I saw him.’Other money comes from corporate and personal donations and the sale of eggs and wool from the animals online. Apart from cash worries, there are other downsides. ‘I’ve had every injury known to man — I’ve lost a nail to a goat horn, been electrocuted by a fence and accidentally injected myself with goat antibiotics,’ says Di.But this pales into insignificance compared to the pain of losing one of their beloved creatures. The sanctuary is full so it’s only with the death of an animal that another can be saved. They come from farm parks, via social media or from other rescue centres.‘It is hard work,’ says Di, ‘but when you see the sheep feeding on the grass and the goats happy in their enclosure, it’s worth it.’          Hen healed in a roasting tray: Buffy the ex-battery hen was doing perfectly well at Manor Farm when she was sat on by another bird and left with a bruised back last winter. ‘One of my biggest joys was that we got Buffy back to health with daily physio,’ says Di. ‘Although I do feel a bit guilty that we kept her in a roasting tray so she could rest her neck on the edge of it. She’s still a bit stiff and walks with a bit of a goose step but is otherwise fine. And she now loves cuddles — every time you pass her she wants you to pick her up.’          Sheep who need a dentist: Dumpy is easy to spot: his teeth have grown so big, his jaw is deformed. ‘But you really couldn’t meet a sweeter sheep,’ says Di. She saved him from the slaughterhouse last year — he was on a trailer bound for it when the farmer’s daughter put out a social media appeal. ‘We all clubbed together to buy him and the farmer said we could have him — as long as we gave the money to Comic Relief,’ says Di. But those teeth keep the dentist busy.

title: Man bit tail rattlesnake tossed neighbors RV argument
story: Ryan Felton Sauter, 39, of Dale, Texas, was arrested and charged with criminal trespass and deadly conduct after allegedly biting the tail off a rattlesnake and putting the snake in his neighbor's RVA Texas man was arrested after allegedly biting the tail off a rattlesnake and putting it in his neighbor's RV following an argument between the two men. Ryan Felton Sauter, 39, of Dale, Texas, was arrested and charged with Class A misdemeanor criminal trespass of a habitation and deadly conduct following the incident which occurred on June 17.After an argument with his neighbor, Keith Monroe, Sauter allegedly found a rattlesnake and used his own teeth to bite its tail off, so the snake could not be heard when it attacked.Sauter is accused of then putting the maimed rattlesnake inside Monroe's RV.Monroe told the Austin-American Statesman he saw Sauter leave his RV and asked him why he was in his home without his permission. According to Monroe, Sauter said, 'You'll see why.' In an effort to figure out what Sauter meant, Monroe said he went inside his home and, looking around, saw the three-foot-long rattlesnake.'I freaked out,' Monroe told the Statesman. 'I couldn’t believe this happened.'           Sauter's neighbor, Keith Monroe (pictured) said that he and Sauter had an argument prior to the snake incident and that they had long-standing disagreements over multiple issues          Monroe said that he saw Sauter exiting his RV (pictured) and when he asked why Sauter was inside without permission, Sauter said 'you'll see why'           The snake Monroe found in his RV was three feet long. He said he killed it with a macheteFirefighter nearly blinded by July 4th fireworks after a...Share this articleMonroe said he killed the snake with a machete and then called the sheriff's office. According to the arrest affidavit, obtained by KVUE, Monroe told deputies that he was 'in fear of imminent danger of serious bodily injury' after discovering Sauter's alleged actions with the snake.The deputies wrote that they had 'observed that the snake’s rattles had been removed.'   Monroe did not specify what his and Sauter's argument had been about, but said that there were several issues that they had long-standing disagreements about. Sauter was taken into custody Friday and his bail was set for $7,500 for each charge.Rattlesnake revenge? Police say man bit snake, set trap for rival

title: World Cup WAG thinks her
story: Flying the flag: England striker Jamie Vardy's wife RebekahHer sharp-shooting husband could fire England into the World Cup quarter-finals tonight.But as the nation holds its breath, striker Jamie Vardy's wife Rebekah is hogging as much of the limelight as she can – claiming her husband's success is partly down to her.The 36-year-old reality TV star has been doing media interviews almost daily while in Russia with her family.She has also been sharing pictures online of her time with other WAGs, boarding private jets and going on extravagant shopping trips, as well as the inevitable glamorous matchday selfies.Estimates suggest 20million people will watch the game on TV in Britain tonight and 36million pints of beer are expected to be drunk across the country today – 17million in pubs and 19million at home.The British Beer and Pub Association also predicted £25million would be spent on food in pubs today and £30million on meals eaten at home.Meanwhile, the National Grid expects electricity demand to spike by 700 megawatts at half-time – equivalent to 27million fridge doors opening at the same time as fans grab another beer.The grid's director of system operations Duncan Burt said: 'We'll balance supply and demand second by second in real time.'  Rebekah Vardy (pictured at England's game against Belgium, left, and on social media, right) has been doing media interviews almost daily while in Russia with her family and sharing pictures online England face Colombia at 7pm in the 45,000-seater Spartak Stadium in Moscow, with around 4,000 of their fans thought to have travelled to Russia. Mrs Vardy will be there too of course, cheering the team – and herself – on.She claimed yesterday the national side had prospered thanks to the presence of their loved ones.Kim Kardashian proves she IS a Beyonce fan as she bops along...Love Island: Megan cements viewers' opinions that she is a...Love Island: Georgia is left RAGING as Josh re-couples with...Adorable moment Limbani the chimpanzee shrieks with joy and...Share this articleShe said coach Gareth Southgate has helped get the most out of the players by allowing them time alone with their families and friends, unlike during previous tournaments.She told The Sun: 'He's got the right idea of the team mentality. He's really relaxed with the players and he makes an effort with all of the families.'He really encourages family days after games, which relaxes the players – it brings a bit of normality in'.

title: The gloriously British summer party
story: Anyone for tennis? Tennis fans soak up the atmosphere at WimbledonTony, who lives just down the road from the Tennis Club — and is already hoarse after shouting 'Taxi! Only two pounds fifty!' from 5.10am — is one of the thousands, many of them enterprising locals, who form the Wimbledon community until a week on Sunday.Most never make it past the hallowed gates of Wimbledon to watch the action on Centre Court, eat overpriced strawberries and drink Pimm's.Instead they spend their (very long) days offering their services to the crowds outside the grounds — selling everything from ice cold water to picnic blankets, Panama hats, designer denim jackets, umbrellas (this week doubling as parasols) and sun cream.'Roger, can I have your headband pleeease!!': Federer gets...Game, sweat and match! Spectators swelter as temperatures...Share this articleChildren write wonky signs on bits of cardboard and sell home-made lemonade. Grannies bake scones and tea loaves. One lady on the main drag from the station is advertising sewing lessons, for goodness sake. A very pale man in a vest, called Ricky — an ice-cream man in his other life — will be here from 7am to 10.30pm, selling iced water at £1 a bottle. 'I'd never sell warm water, ever!' he swears.Some rent out their gardens for parking (£50 a day) or to people running their own stalls.One family have been paid to have their entire front garden transformed in to a Hawaiian paradise, complete with straw gazebo and fake grass, by a sunglasses manufacturer in a bid to 'increase brand awareness'.           Making a small fortune: Tony Finnan, a London black-cab driver, has had his hair trimmed, buzzed and painted bright fluorescent yellow (complete with white seam)Many of the Wimbledon- fortnight community work horrendous hours and make a huge amount of money.Tennis-ball Tony will be here until 10pm tonight, will do 17-hour days for the rest of the tournament and couldn't be happier about it — he earns a small fortune.'It's a trade secret, but it's absolutely worth doing. ABSOLUTELY.' This year he's going to pay for his son Chris's wedding in Santorini. Although I suspect Tony might be here anyway.'I take a fortnight off my usual work and it's like a holiday,' he says. 'It's not as if the people are football hooligans, are they? They're nice people. It's a nice atmosphere.' Because that's the thing about Wimbledon, it is nice — and gloriously British.Yes the Tube is overcrowded, the streets are seething and the sun is doing its best to shrivel the stunning purple, green and white hanging baskets, but somehow no one is shoving or pushing or being remotely irritable.Even the thousands of hot, sweaty people in the vast, snaking mass who queue from 6am each day — first for a queue pass and then, again, to actually enter the grounds — are in good form, and arresting to look at in floral dresses and sunhats, teeny shorts and cropped tops, sport socks, daringly undone shirts, sandals and floppy cricket hats.          Hundreds  of Tennis fans queue in the sweltering heat on Day One of the Wimbeldon Tennis championshipsMeanwhile, the shops in the High Street have gone tennis-mad. Tennis balls and the green, white and purple tournament livery colours are in every windowEd Savitt opened Dropshot, an independent coffee shop, just three weeks ago and is enjoying his 'baptism of fire'. A few doors down, at DeRosier Chocolate &amp Coffee Shop, chocolate tennis balls and chocolate racquets are flying off the shelves.And everywhere you look are dozens of well-heeled and unfailingly polite volunteer stewards sporting bright orange hi-viz jackets, official armbands and a splendid array of Panama hats.There is also an army of professional stewards, which includes Maurice, 68, a retired custody officer. His fluorescent yellow suit is almost too bright to look at as he barks happily at people wandering into the traffic with their noses deep in their phones.Recently widowed Maurice is currently in the middle of summer's stewarding 'season' and loving it.'I've just done Royal Ascot — I did the parking there — 4,000 cars!' Next he's up to Scotland for the European golf tour, followed by a trip to Everest Base Camp in October — something he'd always wanted to do — to commemorate his late wife. His fellow stewards are supporting him financially.He'll be on his feet for 14 hours a day and then home for a long soak in the bath and a huge glass of red wine. 'By the last Sunday I'll be dead on my feet,' he chirps happily. 'I do it every year!'Maurice's spot, a few hundred feet from the Club, is in the epicentre of Joanna Doniger's rental empire, TennisLondon.co.uk, a sort of posh Airbnb for people or corporates who can afford £12,000 for the fortnight, want sleek modern properties and Joanna at their beck and call.This year, the heat has bought fresh challenges, including a glass shower cubicle that exploded in the heat ('luckily no one was in it'), and requests for air-conditioning units and top-of-the-range fans.          This year, the heat has bought fresh challenges for tennis fans waiting in line for tickets None of which is demanded by the thousands camping out this week. There isn't even a shower block in the official camping field.'It's fine,' says Rita, from Melton Mowbray, who is here for the full fortnight with friends Gillian, Anne and Maggie. 'We've got wet wipes and a bucket and we have a strip wash in the loos.'This is their sixth year running and Maggie, 18 yesterday, couldn't think of anywhere she'd prefer to spend her landmark birthday.'It's such fun and everyone is kind and friendly,' she says.Even those who join me at the end of the queue at 12.05pm, where the temperature is 29 degrees and the wait is six hours minimum, are full of the party spirit.No one seems to care that the chances of getting in are minimal. Not even the two ladies I meet who have moved just once (yes, really) since joining the queue at 7.15 this morning.'Time doesn't exist any more,' says Chris, from Nottingham. 'But we're having a very nice time.'More than half the campers aren't even bothering to queue today. They're just enjoying the scene, reading, sunbathing, playing football, listening to music.Natalie, a 33-year-old events organiser is here for the eighth year in a row. She and her friend Lila, are stripped almost off in teeny bikinis and drinking gin and tonics garnished with strawberries.'Every year I want to see Andy Murray here and every year I've failed,' says Natalie.          Wimbledon fortnight is about so much more than the tennis. It is a rite of passage. Pictured, Tatjana Maria in action on day One of the WimbledonNext door but one, the ladies are drinking Prosecco, bought from McClusky's, a corner shop decked out in green and purple. 'The nicest shop in the world!' they trill in unison.Eamon McClusky's family have been running the shop for 62 years, but this promises to be their best yet. He has ordered 50 extra cases of Prosecco, gallons of Pimm's and is overflowing with ice. He will be open from 6am to 11pm and has a 'Wimbledon table' selling everything from instant porridge to sunhats, sunglasses to sandwiches.But not everyone's in it for the money. Over the years, residents have raised tens of thousands for charity by renting out their drives, gardens and even homes.Some rabbis running a popular food stall are raising money for a local Jewish outreach programme.And Jack and Chloe, selling Panama hats at £15 a pop outside a vast house on the main drag, tell me the 'very, very nice' lady who owns the house lets them have the spot in return for a donation to Macmillan Cancer Support.Wimbledon fortnight is about so much more than the tennis. It is a rite of passage. A wonderful two weeks where you can leave your normal life behind, work incredibly hard, laugh a lot, make a tidy nest egg — then spend the rest of the year looking forward to doing it all again next time.

title: Gay cure therapy outlawed
story: Victim: Dean had two so-called exorcisms before accepting his homosexualityThe Government's LGBT (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender) action plan – backed by £4.5million from Whitehall – also promises to hold a consultation on making it easier for people to legally change their sex.Ministers originally promised to allow adults to change their gender legally without a doctor's approval last year, but the plan has been repeatedly delayed amid growing criticism.BBC chief stunned as secret staff sex survey reveals 417 of...Eddie Mair hits back at reports he left the BBC after...Share this article'No one should ever have to hide who they are or who they love. This LGBT action plan will set out concrete steps to deliver real and lasting change across society, from health and education to tackling discrimination and addressing the burning injustices that LGBT people face.'The action plan said the Government will consider 'all legislative and non-legislative options' to prohibit 'promoting, offering or conducting conversion therapy'.It said: 'We will act so that LGBT people feel safe in their own homes and in their communities. Our survey shows that many LGBT people do not report hate incidents they experience and that the abhorrent practice of conversion therapy is still alive in our country.

title: Internet goes wild Thon Makers kung fu karate kicks
story: Thon Maker (centre) of Australia attempts to kick Terrence Romeo (right) of the Philippines          One social media user suggested Maker should be the cover athlete for new wrestling game WWE 2K19'Yo Thon Maker out here tryin hit dudes wit the flying knee,' tweeted Utah Jazz star rookie Donovan Mitchell.'Thon Maker just proved my suspicions that he is part man part kangaroo,' tweeted another man.Other social media users likened Maker's fighting style to the combat video game 'Tekken', with one person claiming the power forward had 'gone full kung-fu'.'Thon Maker comes flying out of nowhere and goes full Bruce Lee, jumping over a guy and protecting his teammates at all costs,' added another.          Utah Jazz star rookie Donovan Mitchell was watching the game live, and was quick to make fun of Maker's 'flying knee' attacks          Other social media users made light of his 'kung-fu' fighting style, posting memes on TwitterThe fight began with four minutes left in the third quarter, when Australian guard Chris Goulding was pushed to the ground following a foul.Teammate Daniel Kickert retaliated by elbowing Philippine's Roger Ray Pogoy in the face, and the teams converged under the Philippines' basket.The most disgraceful scenes in Australia's sporting history?...FIBA to open disciplinary investigation after mass brawl...Share this articleMilwaukee Bucks NBA star Maker launched a flying knee at a group of opposing players, while Philippines centre Andray Blatche blindsided an Australian player with a punch in the back of the head.          Maker (centre) was one of four Australian players ejected from the game  following the fight          With Maker in the midst of a group of Philippines players, 5-foot-11 guard Terrence Romeo struck Maker in the back of the head, causing Maker to turn and chase him with more flying kicks.Maker then played peacemaker, urging his teammates back to the bench, before seeing Australian guard Nathan Sobey up the other end of the court surrounded by Philippines players.Maker was one of four Australian players to be ejected following the fight, which saw the third quarter play out with only three Philippines players remaining in the game.   A disciplinary investigation has been opened by the International Basketball Federation who host the FIBA World Cup, taking place next August.          Basketball fans have flocked to social media to make light of the controversy by turning Maker's actions into a meme

title: Theresa Mays opaque glass old municipal lavatory
story: As superglue drips, so did we all sit through another of Theresa May's parliamentary turns on Brexit. Within seconds, the House was rigidWords may be uttered but they mean – and are designed to mean – nothing. To be so consistently uninformative, so cryptic, as opaque as the glass in an old municipal lavatory, is actually a feat.'We have put forward proposals,' she said about her negotiations with Brussels. 'And we will put forward further proposals.' Er, great.Around the world, political analysts place raw May verbiage into their petri dishes. They crouch over the most modern microscopes to try to detect meaning in these tiny off-cuts. What does the British Prime Minister mean? Which way is she leaning? To British independence? Or to capitulation to the forces of Brussels, Barnier and subsidy-junkie multinationals which want the status quo?These brilliant, white-coated eggheads look up from their instruments, pinkish roundels surrounding their eyes, their Einstein hairdos askew, and for a nanosecond they may think they have a solution.           Officially the Prime Minister was at the despatch box to talk about last week's EU summit but most MPs asked her about Brexit. The optimistic foolsThey sense that Mrs May has let slip a tiny hint as to her true intentions. But then they look again and they wearily have to report to their bosses, no, sorry, we simply haven't a clue what the old girl is saying. She is so comprehensively, ingeniously, glue-ishly uncommunicative.Listening to the shipping forecast in Finnish, back to front, might be more informative.He mentioned fears of a beer drought... MPs gasped: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in Parliament Boris got away without a scrape on his bodywork: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in ParliamentJust tragic! Gothic opera without a decent tune, QUENTIN LETTS reviews The Turn of the Screw Open mutiny from our wet-as-celery Business bloke: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in Parliament QUENTIN LETTS: Meet the faint-hearted, Europhile Business Secretary who spoke with Airbus before the company threatened to quit the UK Wonder bard: QUENTIN LETTS says Cole Porter's musical takes a while to warm up, but once it does it's Too Darn HotWould bouncy Bercow go now? Would he heck: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in Parliament QUENTIN LETTS: Grieve pulled on the khazi chain... yank, clang, sploshHunt and Javid, the decisive duo taking on procrastinating Mrs May and the pfafferati: QUENTIN LETTS on yesterday in ParliamentCertain theories sometimes take hold, as started to happen yesterday – this time claiming that she was about to buckle to her wetly pro-Brussels civil servant, Olly Robbins, who has been trying to bypass the elected David Davis at the Brexit department. Robbins is credited (I am sure without any truth) with trying to tweak the minutes from Whitehall meetings to prevent assurances from Mrs May to Mr Davis being recorded by Civil Service note-takers.Such rumours about Mrs May's Brexit intentions usually begin with newspaper reports or internet gossip and soon become received wisdom that one side or the other in the Brexit battle is going to take a whack on the schnozzle.Mrs May is eventually asked about the rumour and reverts to a worn formula of words which may or may not mean 'nothing has changed'. Yesterday she was asked if she would go for a Norway-style deal, if she would accept the EEA option, if she would let European courts have a say on our laws after Brexit, and much else besides.'There has been much jocularity,' she said, 'about the phrase 'Brexit means Brexit' – but it does mean Brexit.' See? This remark actually drew laughter, it was so classically May-ish.She reiterated that she wanted to do independent British trade deals, to control our own borders and laws, yet still trade with the EU. She says this almost every time she is on parade.           Mrs May is eventually asked about the rumour and reverts to a worn formula of words which may or may not mean 'nothing has changed'Remainers say she cannot possibly achieve all these things, and they wonder how breakfast waiters ever get Mrs May to opt between the kippers and the eggs benedict.She was told she must finally make a choice on Brexit. 'People are fed up with not just Brexit but also with fudge,' hollered Anna Soubry (Con, Broxtowe). Other Europhiles such as Nicky Morgan (Con, Loughborough) and Vicky Ford (Con, Chelmsford) wanted Mrs May to reach a 'pragmatic and practical Brexit' deal – the new euphemism for a cave-in. Mrs May hosed down their pleas with wordy foam.She responded the same way when Leavers such as Jacob Rees-Mogg (Con, NE Somerset) and Bill Cash (Con, Stone) sought nervous reassurances.Short-term forecast: continued, maddening fog.

title: A fifth MPs second job side
story: One in five MPs holds down a second job on the side, the Westminster watchdog has revealedDozens more MPs earn vast sums from irregular work such as speaking engagements, appearing on TV and writing newspaper columns.The committee demanded that Parliament's code of conduct be rewritten to make it clear that MPs should only be allowed to take posts which do not 'compromise their principal role as an MP'.'Gay cure' therapy will be outlawed: Prime Minister Theresa...Boris Johnson BACKS Jacob Rees-Mogg's threats to Theresa May...Share this articleIt said they should only take an outside position with hours within 'reasonable limits', although it did not spell out what this should be. It also recommended that MPs should be banned from working for lobbying firms.The report said: 'A majority of MPs do not hold remunerated outside interests, and a number hold outside interests that can be considered within 'reasonable limits'. However, where a small number of iniduals have taken up outside interests beyond what might be considered reasonable, it risks undermining trust in Parliament and Parliamentarians.'          No MPs are named in the report, but an investigation earlier this year found that the highest paid was Nadhim Zahawi (pictured), the Tory MP for Stratford-on-AvonThe committee said former MPs should register new jobs which put them into contact with ministers. This is designed to tackle the revolving door scandal, where ex-MPs exploit their political contacts in private sector jobs.However, the recommendations need to be passed by Parliament and could simply be rejected.No MPs are named in the report, but an investigation earlier this year found that the highest paid was Nadhim Zahawi, the Tory MP for Stratford-on-Avon.Mr Zahawi, who was chief strategy officer at Gulf Keystone Petroleum, reported outside earnings which were the equivalent of an annual salary of £765,000. He resigned in January after being made Minister for Children and Families.The committee's report found that 18.5 per cent of the 643 MPs have regular, paid outside commitments. In total, they earned £3.35million last year – an average of £28,000 each.

title: Pope Francis makes touching friendship Pope Benedict appointment 14 new cardinals
story: Pope Francis embracing his predecessor at a ceremony to appoint 14 new cardinals in the Vatican          The two men shared a few intimate words before the ceremony. Benedict lives in near isolation in the Vatican Earlier this year it emerged he is battling a disease of his nervous system which means he often needs to use a wheelchair.Benedict said he is in the last phase of life and on a 'pilgrimage towards home' in a letter published in an Italian newspaper.The 81-year-old Pope Francis appointed 14 new from countries Iraq, Pakistan, Madagascar and Japan whom he warned to avoid the kind of 'palace intrigues' which have plagued the Vatican over the years.Each new appointee knelt in front of Pope Francis who placed the cardinal's hat on their heads during the ceremony at St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican.The appointments come as the Argentine pontiff gradually shapes a less European college of cardinals.Before the ceremony marking their appointment, Francis warned the new batch of cardinals that they must not get involved in 'palace intrigues' within the Vatican but focus on 'those who are hungry, the forgotten, the prisoner, the sick, the addict, the abandoned person'.          It recently emerged Benedict was suffering from a disease of the central nervous system Among the most prominent is Iraq's Louis Raphael Sako who has often met Pope Francis to discuss the situation in the war-torn country and the plight of the dwindling Christian community.One third of the Christian families in the north of the country were able to return to their land after the collapse of the Islamic State group, often with funds raised by the church.Sako believes 400,000-500,000 Christians now living in Iraq, compared to 1.5 million before the fall of Saddam Hussein's regime in 2003.Speaking at the beginning of the ceremony, Sako hailed 'the special attention from the Pope... for the small flock of Christians in the Middle East, in Pakistan and other countries that are going through a difficult period because of wars and sectarianism and where there are still martyrs.'  Francis and Benedict with the news cardinals, who come from a total of 14 countries Speaking about his homeland, he said:'It's is our land, we were here before the arrival of Muslims', Sako told journalists on Wednesday.He advocates 'dialogue' and challenges 'a vision of a uniquely Islamic nation'.Also appointed was Pakistani bishop Joseph Coutts of Karachi who promotes dialogue between Christians and Muslims.Coutts fights the abusive use of the crime of blasphemy in a country where churches are under police protection due to threats from extremist Muslim groups.Pope Francis Ireland visit: All you need to know about the...Share this articleThe Pope also appointed Thomas Aquinas Manyo from Osaka in Japan and aong the three Latin American prelates is Archbishop Pedro Barreto of Huancayo, Peru.Barreto fights for the rights of the communities living in the Amazon forest and has received death threats for denouncing working conditions in illegal mines.Seven European cardinals were also appointed, including Italy's Giuseppe Petrocchi, archbishop of L'Aquila, a city destroyed nine years ago by a violent earthquake.Benedict resigned following a turbulent papacy that included the so-call 'Vatileaks' case, in which his butler leaked some of his personal letters and other documents that alleged corruption and a power struggle in the Vatican.

title: Brazen sunbather ruins couples wedding photos refusing move
story: The bikini-clad woman had positioned herself on a towel just yards from where the newlyweds had their photographs takenShe had travelled down from south London to attend the wedding of her father's cousin Mark Ling and Mandy Cripwell on Saturday.The loved up couple were married at Furrough Cross Church in Torquay, which is next to Tessier Gardens - a popular area with newly weds.'Have some f***ing respect': Pathetic social media trolls...Boris Becker blasts back! Tennis star insists that he's NOT...Share this articleMs Ling told Devon Live: 'We all spotted her there and thought she would move, but she just didn't. I thought 'how rude!'.'She was surrounded by wedding guests, the couple were behind her and the photographer kept calling different people over for pictures - so she knew what was going on.'She was asked several times to move but just ignored us. Because it was Mark and Mandy's big day, we didn't want the stress of any confrontation.'She added: 'Eventually she got up and left after about 10 minutes of us being there taking photos - but she still left all her stuff there.'It was ****** rude and disrespectful.'          The wedding party looked confused at the woman who refused to budge from the spot

title: Viewers say GOD walking sky storm footage
story: The amazing footage was caught on camera by Solo Dolo on her Facebook Live'I regret calling her a Qatar w****': Daughter of former Sky...Share this articleThe camera then focuses on the bright white patch on the horizon and adds: 'Look at that hole right in the sky... that's who's got the power.'A short while later, the voice recording the video says: 'He got us covered at least, we're alright.'  Yet it was not until uploading the video where a friend pointed out the strange shape which resembled a human body in the clouds, which some people are claiming to be God.Viewers were quick to point out a shadowy figure which looks like it has arms and legs walking between the bright patch in the clouds.          The footage has been watched more than one million times since it was uploaded onto the social media platform on ThursdayReplying to someone who wrote on the post, Solo Dolo wrote: 'Can't tell me my God ain't real! Thank you God for using Lisa StandAlone Baker to reveal this to me. Too see this is to believe this.'The full video has been viewed more than one million times on Facebook and had more than 7,000 comments since it was uploaded last Thursday.

title: Hard partying Malia Obama celebrates 20th birthday Montauk
story: Photos obtained exclusively by DailyMail.com show Malia Obama partying at the Montauk hot spot, Surf Lodge, as she celebrated her 20th birthday on Saturday afternoonShe said the group arrived on Saturday afternoon and stayed for about an hour while smoking cigarettes and 'partying'.'At one point she was just standing in a bikini,' the insider said. 'She wasn't in a good state, I can tell you that.'The insider added that it appeared as though no one in Malia's group was drinking alcohol.Photos show wine glasses on tables near Malia at the restaurant, though the one closest to her was empty and a bottle of coconut water sat beside it. Other nearby glasses were filled with a pinkish clear liquid.In one image, Malia can be eating a snack, which looks like it could be a bagel with lox.A short video clip of the party obtained by DailyMail.com shows Malia grooving to the music as she sits with a group of friends - both men and women - who appear to be her age.Surf Lodge is a favorite of the former first daughter, who was spotted there last year as well when she celebrated her birthday.           An insider told DailyMail.com that it appeared as though no one in Malia's group was drinking alcohol. Photos show wine glasses on tables near Malia at the restaurant, though the one closest to her was empty and a bottle of coconut water sat beside it          Malia wore a T-shirt, white patterned bikini bottoms and sneakers as she partied at the beach club with friendsOne insider told Page Six that Malia knew staff members' names as she partied at the club on Saturday. The Surf Lodge is a famed celebrity haunt, with First Daughter Tiffany Trump partying at the club alongside Joe Biden's granddaughter Naomi last month.The 24-year-old first daughter was also joined by her other socialite friends, including Andrew Warren, Peter Brant Jr., Alex Assouline, and Jesse Bongiovi .Over the same weekend that Malia Obama making a visit to the venue, Christie Brinkley made an appearance to celebrate her wine brand, Bellissima.The Surf Lodge, a restaurant and hotel, offers live musical acts throughout the summer, with acts including Jessie J, Janelle Monae, Jaden Smith and Lupe Fiasco performing this summer.Over the last decade, the venue has faced a number of noise and zoning violations, and was even forced to temporarily stop its live music program in 2016 over the charges.Back in 2012, it was forced to pay a record-setting $100,000 fine to East Hampton over hundreds of violations.That same year, the venue was bought by Montauk Properties, who at the time said it didn't 'expect to have any of these type of issues going forward'. Braving the heat on summer break! The Harvard student, currently on summer break was all smiles as she was spotted out with her bestie.The former first daughter was sporting a cropped t-shirt with a pair of killer Topshop jeans that are super on trend with their nineties high waist and cropped hemline.Loving this look?
